Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In January of 1995, Russia detected
a nuclear missile headed its way. The alert went all the way
to the president, who was deciding whether to strike back when another system contradicted
the initial warning. What they thought was the first missile
in a massive attack was actually a research rocket
studying the Northern Lights. This incident happened 
after the end of the Cold War, but was nevertheless one of the closest
calls we’ve had to igniting a global nuclear war. With the invention of the atomic bomb, humanity gained the power to destroy
itself for the first time in our history. Since then, our existential risk— risk of either extinction or the unrecoverable collapse 
of human civilization— has steadily increased. It’s well within our power
to reduce this risk, but in order to do so, we have to understand which 
of our activities pose existential threats now, 
and which might in the future. So far, our species has survived
2,000 centuries, each with some extinction risk
from natural causes— asteroid impacts, supervolcanoes,
and the like. Assessing existential risk is 
an inherently uncertain business because usually when we try to figure out
how likely something is, we check how often it's happened before. But the complete destruction of humanity
has never happened before. While there’s no perfect method to
determine our risk from natural threats, experts estimate it’s about 
1 in 10,000 per century. Nuclear weapons were our first
addition to that baseline. While there are many risks associated
with nuclear weapons, the existential risk comes
from the possibility of a global nuclear war that leads
to a nuclear winter, where soot from burning cities
blocks out the sun for years, causing the crops that humanity
depends on to fail. We haven't had a nuclear war yet, but our track record is too short to tell
if they’re inherently unlikely or we’ve simply been lucky. We also can’t say for sure whether a global nuclear war
would cause a nuclear winter so severe it would pose an existential threat
to humanity. The next major addition to our existential
risk was climate change. Like nuclear war, 
climate change could result in a lot of terrible scenarios 
that we should be working hard to avoid, but that would stop short of causing
extinction or unrecoverable collapse. We expect a few degrees
Celsius of warming, but can’t yet completely 
rule out 6 or even 10 degrees, which would cause a calamity of possibly
unprecedented proportions. Even in this worst-case scenario, it’s not clear whether warming would pose
a direct existential risk, but the disruption it would cause
would likely make us more vulnerable to other existential risks. The greatest risks may come 
from technologies that are still emerging. Take engineered pandemics. The biggest catastrophes in human history
have been from pandemics. And biotechnology is enabling
us to modify and create germs that could be much more deadly
than naturally occurring ones. Such germs could cause pandemics 
through biowarfare and research accidents. Decreased costs of genome sequencing
and modification, along with increased availability
of potentially dangerous information like the published genomes 
of deadly viruses, also increase the number of people
and groups who could potentially create
such pathogens. Another concern is unaligned AI. Most AI researchers think this will be
the century where we develop artificial intelligence
that surpasses human abilities across the board. If we cede this advantage, we place
our future in the hands of the systems we create. Even if created solely with humanity’s 
best interests in mind, superintelligent AI could pose 
an existential risk if it isn’t perfectly aligned 
with human values— a task scientists are finding
extremely difficult. Based on what we know at this point, some experts estimate the anthropogenic
existential risk is more than 100 times higher 
than the background rate of natural risk. But these odds depend heavily
on human choices. Because most of the risk is from human
action, and it’s within human control. If we treat safeguarding humanity's future
as the defining issue of our time, we can reduce this risk. Whether humanity fulfils its potential— or not— is in our hands.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are some examples of possible existential threats to humanity?
Options: A. Nuclear weapons, B. Climate Change, C. A large asteroid hitting Earth, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

In January of 1995, Russia detected
a nuclear missile headed its way. The alert went all the way

action, and it’s within human control. If we treat safeguarding humanity's future
as the defining issue of our time, we can reduce this risk. Whether humanity fulfils its potential— or not— is in our hands.

Options: A. It can accelerate climate change by warming up the Earth, B. It can lead to more illnesses and global pandemics, C. It might cause a severe nuclear winter, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

that we should be working hard to avoid, but that would stop short of causing
extinction or unrecoverable collapse. We expect a few degrees
Celsius of warming, but can’t yet completely 
rule out 6 or even 10 degrees, which would cause a calamity of possibly
unprecedented proportions. Even in this worst-case scenario, it’s not clear whether warming would pose
a direct existential risk, but the disruption it would cause
would likely make us more vulnerable to other existential risks. The greatest risks may come 
from technologies that are still emerging. Take engineered pandemics. The biggest catastrophes in human history
have been from pandemics. And biotechnology is enabling
us to modify and create germs that could be much more deadly
than naturally occurring ones. Such germs could cause pandemics 
through biowarfare and research accidents. Decreased costs of genome sequencing
and modification, along with increased availability
of potentially dangerous information like the published genomes 
of deadly viruses, also increase the number of people
and groups who could potentially create
such pathogens. Another concern is unaligned AI. Most AI researchers think this will be
the century where we develop artificial intelligence
that surpasses human abilities across the board. If we cede this advantage, we place
our future in the hands of the systems we create. Even if created solely with humanity’s 
best interests in mind, superintelligent AI could pose 
an existential risk if it isn’t perfectly aligned 
with human values— a task scientists are finding
extremely difficult. Based on what we know at this point, some experts estimate the anthropogenic
existential risk is more than 100 times higher 
than the background rate of natural risk. But these odds depend heavily
on human choices. Because most of the risk is from human
action, and it’s within human control. If we treat safeguarding humanity's future
as the defining issue of our time, we can reduce this risk. Whether humanity fulfils its potential— or not— is in our hands.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of existential risk is more likely to occur in our lifetime?
Options: A. anthropogenic existential risk, B. natural existential risk
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What event occurred in January 1995 that brought the world close to a global nuclear war? Options: A. A research rocket studying the Northern Lights was mistaken for a nuclear missile., B. A massive nuclear attack on Russia was detected., C. A global nuclear war broke out between the United States and Russia., D. A nuclear winter occurred due to a massive nuclear explosion. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the estimated rate of natural existential risk per century? Options: A. 1 in 10, B. 1 in 10,000, C. 1 in 100,000, D. 1 in 1,000,000 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary concern associated with nuclear weapons? Options: A. The risk of a global nuclear war leading to a nuclear winter., B. The risk of a massive nuclear attack on a single country., C. The risk of nuclear radiation poisoning., D. The risk of nuclear meltdowns. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the potential consequence of a global nuclear war? Options: A. A short-term economic crisis., B. A long-term environmental disaster., C. A catastrophic collapse of human civilization., D. A minor disruption to global trade. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the estimated rate of anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk? Options: A. Less than 10 times higher, B. More than 100 times higher, C. The same as the background rate, D. Lower than the background rate Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary concern associated with climate change? Options: A. The risk of a global nuclear war., B. The risk of a massive nuclear attack on a single country., C. The risk of catastrophic collapse of human civilization., D. The risk of unprecedented environmental disaster. Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the potential consequence of engineered pandemics? Options: A. A short-term economic crisis., B. A long-term environmental disaster., C. A catastrophic collapse of human civilization., D. A minor disruption to global trade. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary concern associated with unaligned AI? Options: A. The risk of a global nuclear war., B. The risk of a massive nuclear attack on a single country., C. The risk of catastrophic collapse of human civilization., D. The risk of superintelligent AI surpassing human abilities. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the defining issue of our time according to the text? Options: A. Reducing anthropogenic existential risk., B. Addressing climate change., C. Preventing global nuclear war., D. Safeguarding humanity's future. Correct Option: D
Question 10: Who has control over reducing anthropogenic existential risk? Options: A. Governments and international organizations., B. Individuals and communities., C. Scientists and experts., D. Humans as a whole. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question is about comparing the rate of anthropogenic existential risk to the background rate of natural risk, which is related to the ground truth MCQ's focus on the likelihood of anthropogenic versus natural existential risk. Although the question phrasing and options are not identical, the content and intent are similar.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vagina harbors hundreds of different
kinds of microorganisms. Some tend to be especially prevalent,
like Lactobacilli. These bacteria produce an acid 
that lowers the vagina’s pH, limiting what can survive there and
preventing against certain infections. Candida yeasts are also usually present
in small quantities. Most of the time, 
these fungi are harmless. The body’s immune system keeps them 
in check while other microorganisms, like Lactobacilli, combat and outcompete
them for nutrients and territory. But under certain conditions, 
Candida yeasts can cause infections. One species in particular,
called Candida albicans, is the usual culprit of vaginal thrush
or yeast infections, which affect 3 out of every 4 people 
with a vagina. So, how exactly does a yeast
infection happen? Candida albicans yeasts are shapeshifters. And when the balance within the vagina
is disrupted— like the pH increases or there are 
fewer microbes to compete with— Candida albicans may assume 
their disease-causing forms. They multiply and metamorphose— substituting their rounded structures for elongated thread-like forms 
called hyphae. Then, they secrete enzymes that degrade
the epithelial cells lining the vagina and permeate the tissue. Immune cells rush to the site, generating some of the most recognizable
symptoms of yeast infections: itching, burning, swelling, and redness. These may also be accompanied
by a change in vaginal discharge, the fluid that’s frequently flushed from
the vagina to keep it healthy and clean. During a yeast infection,
discharge may become thicker and whiter because the vagina is shedding 
more epithelial and Candida cells. A few major factors, like 
antibiotic treatments and lower immunity, can make people more susceptible 
to vaginal yeast infections. When someone’s immune system is
compromised, from illness or otherwise, their body may be unable to control
Candida effectively. And in treating bacterial infections,
antibiotics kill harmful bacteria, but they can also wipe out beneficial 
ones, like Lactobacilli, allowing Candida to multiply more easily. Many other factors also help set
the stage for yeast infections. Hormonal changes and diet alter
the vaginal microbiome. Semen is relatively basic, 
so it can disrupt the vagina’s pH. Tight, non-breathable, and wet garments
incubate moisture and are thought to facilitate
a more Candida-friendly environment. Soaps can damage the protective
mucus that coats the vagina, making it easier for Candida to permeate. That’s why many doctors recommend
just gently washing the vulva with water. And it’s important to wipe 
from front to back to avoid introducing more Candida as well 
as other potentially harmful microbes to the vagina. Most yeast infections are mild 
and clear up within two weeks. Antifungal medications usually offer
dependable treatments by reducing the number of Candida cells, allowing the immune system and 
other microorganisms to regain control. And interestingly, the solution 
to treating some yeast infections could be more yeasts. Preliminary studies with probiotics 
containing the harmless yeasts we use in brewing and baking have shown 
promise in keeping Candida in check while reducing inflammation. But some yeast infections
require more extensive therapies. About 5 to 10% of people with vaginas experience at least 4 yeast infections 
a year. For some of those, 
the cause seems to be genetic. Some people have gene variants that make
it harder for their immune systems to recognize and regulate Candida cells. But why many others have recurrent
infections is currently unclear— and requires a lot more research. In fact, so does basically everything
we've just talked about. We don’t know nearly enough 
about the vaginal microbiome. This is probably because of stigma
and underfunding when it comes to topics that traditionally
fall under the umbrella of “women’s health.” For instance, while erectile dysfunction
affects a much smaller percentage of people than vaginal yeast infections, there’s about 6 times more
research on the subject. Hopefully, we’ll soon have
a better understanding of the many microorganismal multitudes 
we contain— and how best to keep them in balance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which type of bacteria are most prevalent in the human vagina?
Options: A. Escherichia, B. Lactobacillus, C. Bifidobacterium, D. Gardnerella
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of bacteria is commonly found in the vagina and helps to prevent infections? Options: A. Lactobacilli, B. Candida, C. E. coli, D. Staphylococcus Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main reason why Candida yeasts can cause infections in the vagina? Options: A. The body's immune system is unable to recognize them, B. The pH in the vagina increases, allowing Candida to multiply, C. The body's immune system is unable to control their growth, D. Candida yeasts are toxic to the vagina's epithelial cells Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is a common symptom of a vaginal yeast infection? Options: A. A decrease in vaginal discharge, B. A change in vaginal discharge, including a thicker and whiter consistency, C. A decrease in body temperature, D. An increase in body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 4: What can happen to the vagina's pH when semen is introduced during sex? Options: A. The pH increases, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply, B. The pH decreases, making it easier for Candida to multiply, C. The pH remains the same, with no effect on Candida, D. The pH becomes more alkaline, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a recommended way to avoid introducing more Candida to the vagina during wiping? Options: A. Wipe from front to back, B. Wipe from back to front, C. Wipe in a circular motion, D. Wipe with soap Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential cause of recurrent vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Genetic predisposition, B. Hormonal changes, C. Diet, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a common treatment for vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Antibiotics, B. Antifungal medications, C. Probiotics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a potential benefit of using probiotics to treat vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. They can reduce the number of Candida cells, B. They can increase the number of Candida cells, C. They can reduce inflammation, D. They can have no effect on Candida Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a reason why there is a lack of research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Stigma surrounding women's health, C. Lack of interest in the topic, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of underfunding research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. A lack of understanding of the vaginal microbiome, B. An increase in the number of vaginal yeast infections, C. A decrease in the number of vaginal yeast infections, D. No effect on the number of vaginal yeast infections Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the type of bacteria most prevalent in the vagina) and options (both questions include Lactobacillus as the correct answer). The content of the two questions is also similar, with both questions referring to the role of Lactobacillus in preventing infections.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

The vagina harbors hundreds of different
kinds of microorganisms. Some tend to be especially prevalent,

Options: A. Yeast cells, B. Chlamydospores, C. Hyphae, D. Opaque cells
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

kinds of microorganisms. Some tend to be especially prevalent,

require more extensive therapies. About 5 to 10% of people with vaginas experience at least 4 yeast infections 
a year. For some of those, 
the cause seems to be genetic. Some people have gene variants that make
it harder for their immune systems to recognize and regulate Candida cells. But why many others have recurrent
infections is currently unclear— and requires a lot more research. In fact, so does basically everything
we've just talked about. We don’t know nearly enough 
about the vaginal microbiome. This is probably because of stigma
and underfunding when it comes to topics that traditionally
fall under the umbrella of “women’s health.” For instance, while erectile dysfunction
affects a much smaller percentage of people than vaginal yeast infections, there’s about 6 times more
research on the subject. Hopefully, we’ll soon have
a better understanding of the many microorganismal multitudes 
we contain— and how best to keep them in balance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why can antibiotics cause fungal infections?
Options: A. Because they lower the pH, B. Because they cause a hormonal imbalance, C. Because they damage the protective mucus layer, D. Because they kill the natural competitors of the fungi
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of bacteria is commonly found in the vagina and helps to prevent infections? Options: A. Lactobacilli, B. Candida, C. E. coli, D. Staphylococcus Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main reason why Candida yeasts can cause infections in the vagina? Options: A. The body's immune system is unable to recognize them, B. The pH in the vagina increases, allowing Candida to multiply, C. The body's immune system is unable to control their growth, D. Candida yeasts are toxic to the vagina's epithelial cells Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is a common symptom of a vaginal yeast infection? Options: A. A decrease in vaginal discharge, B. A change in vaginal discharge, including a thicker and whiter consistency, C. A decrease in body temperature, D. An increase in body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 4: What can happen to the vagina's pH when semen is introduced during sex? Options: A. The pH increases, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply, B. The pH decreases, making it easier for Candida to multiply, C. The pH remains the same, with no effect on Candida, D. The pH becomes more alkaline, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a recommended way to avoid introducing more Candida to the vagina during wiping? Options: A. Wipe from front to back, B. Wipe from back to front, C. Wipe in a circular motion, D. Wipe with soap Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential cause of recurrent vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Genetic predisposition, B. Hormonal changes, C. Diet, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a common treatment for vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Antibiotics, B. Antifungal medications, C. Probiotics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a potential benefit of using probiotics to treat vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. They can reduce the number of Candida cells, B. They can increase the number of Candida cells, C. They can reduce inflammation, D. They can have no effect on Candida Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a reason why there is a lack of research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Stigma surrounding women's health, C. Lack of interest in the topic, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of underfunding research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. A lack of understanding of the vaginal microbiome, B. An increase in the number of vaginal yeast infections, C. A decrease in the number of vaginal yeast infections, D. No effect on the number of vaginal yeast infections Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vagina harbors hundreds of different
kinds of microorganisms. Some tend to be especially prevalent,
like Lactobacilli. These bacteria produce an acid 
that lowers the vagina’s pH, limiting what can survive there and
preventing against certain infections. Candida yeasts are also usually present
in small quantities. Most of the time, 
these fungi are harmless. The body’s immune system keeps them 
in check while other microorganisms, like Lactobacilli, combat and outcompete
them for nutrients and territory. But under certain conditions, 
Candida yeasts can cause infections. One species in particular,
called Candida albicans, is the usual culprit of vaginal thrush
or yeast infections, which affect 3 out of every 4 people 
with a vagina. So, how exactly does a yeast
infection happen? Candida albicans yeasts are shapeshifters. And when the balance within the vagina
is disrupted— like the pH increases or there are 
fewer microbes to compete with— Candida albicans may assume 
their disease-causing forms. They multiply and metamorphose— substituting their rounded structures for elongated thread-like forms 
called hyphae. Then, they secrete enzymes that degrade
the epithelial cells lining the vagina and permeate the tissue. Immune cells rush to the site, generating some of the most recognizable
symptoms of yeast infections: itching, burning, swelling, and redness. These may also be accompanied
by a change in vaginal discharge, the fluid that’s frequently flushed from
the vagina to keep it healthy and clean. During a yeast infection,
discharge may become thicker and whiter because the vagina is shedding 
more epithelial and Candida cells. A few major factors, like 
antibiotic treatments and lower immunity, can make people more susceptible 
to vaginal yeast infections. When someone’s immune system is
compromised, from illness or otherwise, their body may be unable to control
Candida effectively. And in treating bacterial infections,
antibiotics kill harmful bacteria, but they can also wipe out beneficial 
ones, like Lactobacilli, allowing Candida to multiply more easily. Many other factors also help set
the stage for yeast infections. Hormonal changes and diet alter
the vaginal microbiome. Semen is relatively basic, 
so it can disrupt the vagina’s pH. Tight, non-breathable, and wet garments
incubate moisture and are thought to facilitate
a more Candida-friendly environment. Soaps can damage the protective
mucus that coats the vagina, making it easier for Candida to permeate. That’s why many doctors recommend
just gently washing the vulva with water. And it’s important to wipe 
from front to back to avoid introducing more Candida as well 
as other potentially harmful microbes to the vagina. Most yeast infections are mild 
and clear up within two weeks. Antifungal medications usually offer
dependable treatments by reducing the number of Candida cells, allowing the immune system and 
other microorganisms to regain control. And interestingly, the solution 
to treating some yeast infections could be more yeasts. Preliminary studies with probiotics 
containing the harmless yeasts we use in brewing and baking have shown 
promise in keeping Candida in check while reducing inflammation. But some yeast infections
require more extensive therapies. About 5 to 10% of people with vaginas experience at least 4 yeast infections 
a year. For some of those, 
the cause seems to be genetic. Some people have gene variants that make
it harder for their immune systems to recognize and regulate Candida cells. But why many others have recurrent
infections is currently unclear— and requires a lot more research. In fact, so does basically everything
we've just talked about. We don’t know nearly enough 
about the vaginal microbiome. This is probably because of stigma
and underfunding when it comes to topics that traditionally
fall under the umbrella of “women’s health.” For instance, while erectile dysfunction
affects a much smaller percentage of people than vaginal yeast infections, there’s about 6 times more
research on the subject. Hopefully, we’ll soon have
a better understanding of the many microorganismal multitudes 
we contain— and how best to keep them in balance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some genetic determinants increase frequencies of fungal infections. How?
Options: A. They alter the natural microbiome, B. They alter the local nutrient supply, C. They alter the immune response, D. They alter the genome of the fungus
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What type of bacteria is commonly found in the vagina and helps to prevent infections? Options: A. Lactobacilli, B. Candida, C. E. coli, D. Staphylococcus Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main reason why Candida yeasts can cause infections in the vagina? Options: A. The body's immune system is unable to recognize them, B. The pH in the vagina increases, allowing Candida to multiply, C. The body's immune system is unable to control their growth, D. Candida yeasts are toxic to the vagina's epithelial cells Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is a common symptom of a vaginal yeast infection? Options: A. A decrease in vaginal discharge, B. A change in vaginal discharge, including a thicker and whiter consistency, C. A decrease in body temperature, D. An increase in body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 4: What can happen to the vagina's pH when semen is introduced during sex? Options: A. The pH increases, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply, B. The pH decreases, making it easier for Candida to multiply, C. The pH remains the same, with no effect on Candida, D. The pH becomes more alkaline, making it more difficult for Candida to multiply Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a recommended way to avoid introducing more Candida to the vagina during wiping? Options: A. Wipe from front to back, B. Wipe from back to front, C. Wipe in a circular motion, D. Wipe with soap Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential cause of recurrent vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Genetic predisposition, B. Hormonal changes, C. Diet, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a common treatment for vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Antibiotics, B. Antifungal medications, C. Probiotics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is a potential benefit of using probiotics to treat vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. They can reduce the number of Candida cells, B. They can increase the number of Candida cells, C. They can reduce inflammation, D. They can have no effect on Candida Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a reason why there is a lack of research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Stigma surrounding women's health, C. Lack of interest in the topic, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of underfunding research on the vaginal microbiome? Options: A. A lack of understanding of the vaginal microbiome, B. An increase in the number of vaginal yeast infections, C. A decrease in the number of vaginal yeast infections, D. No effect on the number of vaginal yeast infections Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is a potential cause of recurrent vaginal yeast infections? Options: A. Genetic predisposition, B. Hormonal changes, C. Diet, D. All of the above.

However, the correct answer in the generated MCQ is "D. All of the above," whereas the ground truth MCQ focuses specifically on genetic determinants. A more precise match would be a generated MCQ that directly addresses genetic factors.

Among the provided options, Question 6 is the closest match, but it does not perfectly align with the ground truth MCQ. If I had to choose an index, I would say Question 6 (index 6) is the most similar generated MCQ, but please note that it is not an exact match.

To create a more accurate match, a new generated MCQ could be created that specifically addresses how genetic determinants increase the frequency of fungal infections, with options that include altering the immune response. 

Example:
Question: How do genetic determinants increase the frequency of fungal infections?
Options: A. They alter the natural microbiome, B. They alter the local nutrient supply, C. They alter the immune response, D. They alter the genome of the fungus

This revised question would more closely match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the hagfish secret for surviving shark bites?
Options: A. Cartilage skeleton, B. Loose skin, C. Knot tying, D. Thick armor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the result of a 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying thousands of kilograms of live hagfish? Options: A. The hagfish were killed instantly., B. The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took the fire department 7 hours to clear., C. The truck driver was injured., D. The hagfish were released into the wild. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the standout strength of all hagfish? Options: A. Their ability to swim fast., B. Their keen sense of smell., C. Their slime., D. Their ability to tie knots. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why is the hagfish's slime so effective in defending against predators? Options: A. Because it's made of a hard, brittle material., B. Because it's made of a soft, flexible material that can be easily dislodged., C. Because it's made of a substance that can be easily digested., D. Because it's made of a substance that can be easily broken down. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is unique about the hagfish's body structure that allows it to avoid damage when bitten by a predator? Options: A. Its skin is tightly attached to its body., B. Its skin is loosely attached to its body., C. Its bones are flexible., D. Its muscles are very strong. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a sustainable alternative to non-renewable petroleum-based fibers? Options: A. Hagfish slime threads, B. Nylon, C. Polyester, D. Cotton Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one of the potential uses of hagfish slime in military contexts? Options: A. To stop boats by sliming up their propellers., B. To create a non-lethal weapon that can be used to capture enemies., C. To create a new type of camouflage., D. To create a new type of armor. Correct Option: A
Question 7: How many hearts does a hagfish have? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: D
Question 8: How long can a hagfish survive without oxygen? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 12 hours, C. 36 hours, D. 72 hours Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is one of the ways in which hagfish contribute to the ecosystem? Options: A. By pollinating plants., B. By cleaning the seafloor and cycling essential nutrients., C. By producing oxygen., D. By decomposing organic matter. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How long have hagfish been navigating the ocean's depths? Options: A. Less than 100 million years, B. Less than 300 million years, C. More than 300 million years, D. More than 500 million years Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What is unique about the hagfish's body structure that allows it to avoid damage when bitten by a predator? 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the hagfish's secret for surviving shark bites. The correct option in both questions (B. Loose skin) highlights the unique feature of the hagfish's body structure that allows it to avoid damage when bitten by a predator.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands

its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many times its original volume can hagfish slime expand?
Options: A. 10, B. 100, C. 1,000, D. 10,000
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these is NOT a reason why people are trying to mimic hagfish slime?
Options: A. It is more sustainable than petroleum-based alternatives, B. It can rival the strength of many artificial fibers, C. It is harder than concrete, D. It may be effective at stopping boat propellers
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What’s the best country 
in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?
The longest life expectancy? The best weather? For the past 70 years, most governments 
have relied heavily on a single number to answer that question. This number influences elections, 
the stock market, and government policy. But it was never intended
for its current purpose; and some would argue that the world 
is addicted to making it grow... forever. This number is called 
the Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, and it was invented by the economist
Simon Kuznets in the 1930s, to try and gauge the size of an economy
in a single, easy to understand number. GDP is the total monetary value 
of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those
services aren’t sold on the market. And if a country has a lot of wealth, but most of it is controlled
by relatively few people, GDP per capita gives a distorted picture
of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is GDP?
Options: A. Total value of everything that is bought in a country, B. The total value of everything sold in a country, C. Total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market, D. The total value of an entire country's infrastructure
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the single number that most governments rely on to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Gross Domestic Product (GDP), B. Gross National Happiness (GNH), C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using GDP as a measure of well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it, C. It only measures economic growth, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the name of the alternative metric to GDP that was introduced by King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan in 1972? Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the main difference between GDP and GNH? Options: A. GDP measures economic growth, while GNH measures well-being, B. GDP measures well-being, while GNH measures economic growth, C. GDP and GNH measure the same thing, D. GDP and GNH are not related Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the name of the country that factors in both well-being and the environmental burdens of economic growth? Options: A. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Gross National Happiness (GNH), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the country that has made notable progress in using resources sustainably while also improving living standards? Options: A. Costa Rica, B. Colombia, C. Jordan, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account people's different priorities, C. It obscures important factors that contribute to well-being, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the name of the approach that experts favor over using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Dashboard approach, B. Single number approach, C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what would you measure if you were designing your country's well-being metric? Options: A. Economic growth, B. Well-being outcomes, C. People's priorities, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the transcript about measuring a country's well-being? Options: A. A single number can capture a country's well-being, B. A country's well-being is too complex to measure, C. People have different priorities when it comes to measuring well-being, D. A dashboard approach is the best way to measure well-being Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. However, the options in Question 1 do not directly match the options in the ground truth MCQ.

A closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, if I had to choose the most similar one, I would say that Question 1 is the closest, but with a caveat.

The ground truth MCQ asks "What is GDP?" and provides options that define GDP. Question 1 asks "What is the name of the single number that most governments rely on to measure a country's well-being?" and provides options that include GDP. While the questions are related, they are not identical.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 1 (Index 1), but with the understanding that it's not a perfect match.

It's worth noting that a more accurate generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ would be one that asks "What is GDP?" and provides options that define GDP, such as:

Question: What is GDP?
Options: A. Total value of everything that is bought in a country, B. The total value of everything sold in a country, C. Total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market, D. The total value of an entire country's infrastructure

Unfortunately, this question is not among the generated MCQs provided.

in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?

of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are somethings GDP does NOT capture
Options: A. Services that are provided but not sold on the market place (like public schools and fire fighting), B. Levels of inequality (the amount of people who have wealth vs. who does not), C. How happy people are with their lives, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the single number that most governments rely on to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Gross Domestic Product (GDP), B. Gross National Happiness (GNH), C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using GDP as a measure of well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it, C. It only measures economic growth, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the name of the alternative metric to GDP that was introduced by King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan in 1972? Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the main difference between GDP and GNH? Options: A. GDP measures economic growth, while GNH measures well-being, B. GDP measures well-being, while GNH measures economic growth, C. GDP and GNH measure the same thing, D. GDP and GNH are not related Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the name of the country that factors in both well-being and the environmental burdens of economic growth? Options: A. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Gross National Happiness (GNH), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the country that has made notable progress in using resources sustainably while also improving living standards? Options: A. Costa Rica, B. Colombia, C. Jordan, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account people's different priorities, C. It obscures important factors that contribute to well-being, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the name of the approach that experts favor over using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Dashboard approach, B. Single number approach, C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what would you measure if you were designing your country's well-being metric? Options: A. Economic growth, B. Well-being outcomes, C. People's priorities, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the transcript about measuring a country's well-being? Options: A. A single number can capture a country's well-being, B. A country's well-being is too complex to measure, C. People have different priorities when it comes to measuring well-being, D. A dashboard approach is the best way to measure well-being Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match in terms of question intent and content. Question 2 asks about the main issue with using GDP as a measure of well-being, and one of the correct issues mentioned in the transcript is that GDP "doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it." This is related to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about what GDP does NOT capture, and the correct options include services that are provided but not sold on the market place (like public schools and fire fighting) and levels of inequality (the amount of people who have wealth vs. who does not).

However, a more similar question could be generated to match the ground truth MCQ. For example:

Question: What are some limitations of using GDP as a measure of a country's well-being?
Options: A. It does not account for services that are not sold on the market, B. It does not capture levels of inequality, C. It does not measure people's happiness, D. All of the above.

This generated question would more closely match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. 

Given the provided generated MCQs, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What’s the best country 
in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?
The longest life expectancy? The best weather? For the past 70 years, most governments 
have relied heavily on a single number to answer that question. This number influences elections, 
the stock market, and government policy. But it was never intended
for its current purpose; and some would argue that the world 
is addicted to making it grow... forever. This number is called 
the Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, and it was invented by the economist
Simon Kuznets in the 1930s, to try and gauge the size of an economy
in a single, easy to understand number. GDP is the total monetary value 
of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those
services aren’t sold on the market. And if a country has a lot of wealth, but most of it is controlled
by relatively few people, GDP per capita gives a distorted picture
of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: _____ is an alternative to GDP that captures health, education, strong communities and living standards
Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Gross Domestic Wellbeing (GNW), C. Wholistic Value-Added (WVA), D. Community Aggregate Valuation (CAV)
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the single number that most governments rely on to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Gross Domestic Product (GDP), B. Gross National Happiness (GNH), C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using GDP as a measure of well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it, C. It only measures economic growth, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the name of the alternative metric to GDP that was introduced by King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan in 1972? Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the main difference between GDP and GNH? Options: A. GDP measures economic growth, while GNH measures well-being, B. GDP measures well-being, while GNH measures economic growth, C. GDP and GNH measure the same thing, D. GDP and GNH are not related Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the name of the country that factors in both well-being and the environmental burdens of economic growth? Options: A. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Gross National Happiness (GNH), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the country that has made notable progress in using resources sustainably while also improving living standards? Options: A. Costa Rica, B. Colombia, C. Jordan, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. It is too complex to understand, B. It doesn't take into account people's different priorities, C. It obscures important factors that contribute to well-being, D. It is not widely used Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the name of the approach that experts favor over using a single number to measure a country's well-being? Options: A. Dashboard approach, B. Single number approach, C. Human Development Index (HDI), D. Sustainable Development Index (SDI) Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what would you measure if you were designing your country's well-being metric? Options: A. Economic growth, B. Well-being outcomes, C. People's priorities, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the transcript about measuring a country's well-being? Options: A. A single number can capture a country's well-being, B. A country's well-being is too complex to measure, C. People have different priorities when it comes to measuring well-being, D. A dashboard approach is the best way to measure well-being Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

**Question 3: What is the name of the alternative metric to GDP that was introduced by King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan in 1972? Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Human Development Index (HDI), C. Sustainable Development Index (SDI), D. Well-being Index Correct Option: A**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about an alternative to GDP that captures various aspects of well-being, and both have Gross National Happiness (GNH) as the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4

**Transcript**:
What’s the best country 
in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?
The longest life expectancy? The best weather? For the past 70 years, most governments 
have relied heavily on a single number to answer that question. This number influences elections, 
the stock market, and government policy. But it was never intended
for its current purpose; and some would argue that the world 
is addicted to making it grow... forever. This number is called 
the Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, and it was invented by the economist
Simon Kuznets in the 1930s, to try and gauge the size of an economy
in a single, easy to understand number. GDP is the total monetary value 
of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those
services aren’t sold on the market. And if a country has a lot of wealth, but most of it is controlled
by relatively few people, GDP per capita gives a distorted picture
of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?
